Headline: Longevity Scientist & Preventive Health Founder üöÄ | Advancing Gender-Aware, Equitable Ageing Solutions | Biology x Behaviour x Belonging
Comment:
This post deeply resonates with me. As a founder of a preventive health startup back in 2018, I learned firsthand how hard it is to sell prevention in a world wired for quick fixes.

Having lost both my parents to chronic diseases, I‚Äôve seen the devastating impact of neglected health choices up close. The irony? People turn a blind eye to things until they become chronic issues‚Äîwhether it‚Äôs mental health, metabolic dysfunction, or lifestyle-driven conditions. And when they do act, it‚Äôs often driven by fear, not foresight.

Prevention isn‚Äôt just a business challenge, it‚Äôs a behavioral challenge. People take anecdotal evidence over data, ignore long-term risks, and only act when the cost of inaction becomes unbearable. The real shift will happen when prevention isn‚Äôt sold as ‚Äòhealthcare‚Äô but as status, performance, and convenience‚Äîthings people already prioritize.

If we want prevention to win, we have to meet people where they are. Make it frictionless, rewarding, and aspirational. Package it in a way that taps into what they already desire‚Äîconfidence, success, and longevity. Build for behavior, not just health outcomes. Because the real challenge isn‚Äôt making prevention work‚Äîit‚Äôs making people care before it‚Äôs too late.

Headline: Nature-Based Carbon Projects | ESG for Business | Ex Director at EARTHDAY.ORG
Comment:
Dilip Kumar Reading this made me think about safety‚Äîmuch like preventive health, no one wants to pay for it until disaster strikes. In my early 20s, I was working on a project called SAFER (Safety Awareness, First Aid, and Emergency Response) to set up safety protocols for institutions, especially smaller organizations.

What I observed was shocking‚Äîeven schools barely comply with fire safety norms, no drills are conducted, and organizations ignore even the minimum compliance standards. Yet, there‚Äôs no mindset to pay for safety, even though it‚Äôs critical.

Just like preventive health, disaster preparedness isn‚Äôt ‚Äòurgent‚Äô‚Äîuntil it‚Äôs too late. Projects like these need resource backing and policy push to be sustainable. But even CSRs hesitate to invest in them. Prevention may be a hard sell, but the cost of ignoring it is catastrophic

Headline: Founder @Find My Niche | Niche Strategist | Marketing Coach
Comment:
Dilip Kumar I disagree with your premise. Preventive healthcare is hard because nobody wants to put in the work. Brands tend to rely on influencers to sell rather than educating the audience how they can truly understand their body. You would rarely find brands building communities solely for the purpose of educating people. 
Health is not aspirational. It is the dire need of the moment. You can't cheat your audience by promising 6-pack abs and a calisthenic body just in 30 days. Preventive health doesn't need to be glamourised but portrayed as exactly what it is. It needs to be worked upon, and not just for 3 months or 6 months but for a lifetime. 
If you think people don't care about preventive health, look at the LinkedIn feed around filled with people prioritizing mental health over a secure way of paying their bills.

Headline: üöÄ Founder & CEO | WTF ‚Äì (Gyms, Academy, Amplify, Everyday, Reboot, Digi Gym, Nutrition, OS -Full-Stack Fitness Ecosystem ) | Disrupting India‚Äôs $15B Fitness Market
Comment:
This is exactly the paradox of preventive health‚Äîeveryone acknowledges its importance, yet no one wants to pay for it until it's too late. The challenge isn‚Äôt just awareness; it‚Äôs changing human behavior, which is infinitely harder than treating a crisis.

But the beauty of this challenge is that it demands a full-stack solution‚Äînot just another fitness program, diet plan, or wearable, but an integrated ecosystem that makes prevention effortless, accessible, and rewarding. Enough talk about why prevention is hard; it's time to build a system where prevention just works‚Äîseamlessly embedded in daily life, removing friction, and delivering value upfront instead of years later.

The real opportunity isn‚Äôt in convincing people to care about health but in designing a model where they don‚Äôt have to think about it‚Äîwhere prevention happens automatically. That‚Äôs the real full-stack story.

One aspect in all of this is lack of open, green and natural landscapes in most urban cities. The lack of avenues to connect with nature, fresh air, sunlight, etc. closes people (psychologically) to trying out exercise, or walking/jogging/cycling in the open, etc. Then whenever there is stress, everyone reaches out to whatever instant gratification options are available.

We need natural landscapes - lakes, parks, forests, hills in cities to let people have that sense of excitement and curiosity about going out, being physically active and exploring the world.

Headline: Co-Founder | Investor, Acquiring SMBs @ DarwinX
Comment:
Great post, Dilip Kumar! Out of personal interest, Ive been diving deep into preventive health lately, exploring many theories on a wide-spectrum of opinions.

Then, as I try to ADVOCATE for it with people I care about‚Ä¶. Well, your post perfectly captures the challenge!

Prevention‚Äôs real competition isn‚Äôt "curative health," it‚Äôs Netflix and junk food. The battle is as much about wallets (prioritizing fast vs delayed gratification) than it is for attention.

‚Üí How do we make healthy choices (active) as irresistible as passive scrolling?

From my limited experience, I conclude the problem boils down to a combination of "self-hypnosis" and "apathy."

- People think they‚Äôre invincible (until they‚Äôre not.)
- People don't want to think about what scares them (aka Ostrich Policy).

Prevention doesn‚Äôt sell because it‚Äôs TOO POLITE. Because it's sold to the WRONG INSTINCTS.

It's sad, but people don‚Äôt act until they‚Äôre scared or shamed. Not because they need "more education" and "awareness campaigns."

WHAT IF prevention didn't shy away from BRUTAL HONESTY?

‚Üí ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre not tired, you‚Äôre UNFIT"
‚Üí "You‚Äôre not busy, you‚Äôre UNDISCIPLINED‚Äù

Could truth sell better than hope? It'd polarize more, for sure. But the "net effect?"

Comment:
Absolutely agree‚Äîbuilding a business in preventive health is tough. But there's another challenge we often overlook: the way we define "healthcare" itself.

Today, most of what we call healthcare is actually disease care‚Äîreactive solutions rather than proactive well-being. Prevention isn't just a "good-to-do" habit; it's a way of life. And to make it mainstream, we need to rethink how it's positioned.

‚úÖ Wellness isn‚Äôt expensive‚Äîit‚Äôs misunderstood.
Preventive health can be as affordable as a monthly grocery budget. The real gap isn‚Äôt cost; it‚Äôs knowledge. This is where professionals, doctors, and health experts play a crucial role‚Äînot just in treatment, but in making prevention practical and attractive.

‚úÖ Behavior change isn‚Äôt about logic, it‚Äôs about desire.
Telling people to avoid unhealthy habits isn‚Äôt enough. Just like kids need a candy to build a habit, adults need incentives to embrace prevention. The best health solutions don‚Äôt just inform‚Äîthey inspire and integrate into daily life seamlessly.

If prevention is the future of healthcare, then professionals must sell what people want to deliver what they need. That‚Äôs how we shift from a reactive system to a truly preventive one.

#Healthcare #PreventiveHealth #Wellness

Headline: Alumni WSP2 NSRCEL,IIMB, Physiotherapist | Certified Pediatric Posture Specialist | Innovator & Founder at Innobody Systems & InnoPhyzio HealthTech | Director of Operations at Innomitra
Comment:
Same with Physiotherapy!
In today‚Äôs healthcare market, people readily spend on expensive treatment packages filled with machines and passive modalities but hesitate to pay for a physiotherapist‚Äôs consultation. This mindset neglects the true value of physiotherapy‚Äîexpert assessment, movement correction, and guided rehabilitation.
While modalities like ultrasound, IFT, and TENS may provide temporary relief, they do not address the root cause of pain or dysfunction. True healing and long-term recovery come from a physiotherapist‚Äôs expertise in hands-on therapy, exercise prescription, and most importantly, preventive healthcare.
Physiotherapy is not just about treating pain; it is about preventing it. Regular assessments, posture correction, and guided exercises can help avoid chronic conditions, improve mobility, and enhance overall well-being. Investing in a physiotherapy consultation isn‚Äôt just about recovery‚Äîit‚Äôs about building a healthier, pain-free future.
